column1: A group of English Quakers from the Plymouth Colony—who as pacifists held ideological differences with the Puritans on the question of taxes to fund a military—separated and established the first European settlement on the South Coast in 1652. They purchased Old Dartmouth—a region that is now Dartmouth

column6: the Wampanoags did not share the settlers' concepts of private property. The tribe may have understood they were granting usage rights to the land
column7: not giving it up permanently.

column1: The American Revolutionary War completely paralyzed the whaling industry. column1: The Bristol County Sheriff's Office operates the Ash Street Jail and Regional Lock-Up and the Juvenile Secure Alternative Lock Up Program (JALP) in New Bedford. The Ash Street jail houses over 200 pre-trial prisoners and a few sentenced inmate workers for the system. JALP houses up to 12 pre-arraignment juvenile prisoners.

column1: The economy of the Pilgrim settlement in the New Bedford area was initially based around a few farming and fishing villages. The early Bedford Village quickly became a commercial zone and from there became a major whaling and foreign trade port. In the early 18th century
column2: the Russell family purchased this area and developed it into a larger village (Joseph Russell III having made the most significant contributions). Age of Sail ships built in New Bedford include the schooner Caroline and whaleship Charles W. Morgan. By the 18th century
column3: entrepreneurs in the area
column4: such as whaling merchants from Nantucket
column5: were attracted to the village and helped make it into one of the top whaling cities in the country. The most significant of these merchants was Joseph Rotch
column6: who bought 10 acres (four hectares) of land in 1765 from Joseph Russell III on which he and his sons ran the family business. Rotch moved his business to New Bedford since it would be better for refining whale oil and manufacturing candles made from whales. As these parts of the whaling industry had been monopolized by a merchant cartel in Boston
column7: Newport
column8: Rhode Island
column9: and Providence
column11: Rotch felt that it would be better for business to handle these himself by moving to the mainland.

column1: The relationship between New Bedford and Nantucket allowed the two cities to dominate the whaling industry. In 1848 New Bedford resident Lewis Temple invented the toggling harpoon
column2: an invention that would revolutionize the whaling industry. This helped make New Bedford the preeminent city in the U.S. whaling industry. Another factor was the increased draft of whaling ships
column3: in part the result of greater use of steel in their construction
column4: which made them too deep for Nantucket harbor. Syren
column5: the longest lived of the clipper ships
column6: spent over a decade transporting whale oil and whaling products to New Bedford
column7: principally from Honolulu
column8: and was owned for several years by William H. Besse of New Bedford. As a result of its control over whaling products that were used widely throughout the world (most importantly whale oil)
column9: New Bedford became one of the richest per capita cities in the world.

column1: Many whalers would quit their jobs in 1849
column2: though
column3: as the Gold Rush attracted many of them to leave New Bedford for California. During this time Herman Melville
column4: who worked in New Bedford as a whaler
column5: wrote the novel Moby-Dick and published it in 1851; the city would be the initial setting of the book
column6: including a scene set in the Seaman's Bethel
column7: which still stands today. Despite the power it gave to New Bedford
column8: the whaling industry began to decline starting in 1859 when petroleum
column9: which would become an alternative to whale oil
column10: was discovered. Another blow came with the Whaling Disaster of 1871
column11: in which twenty-two New Bedford whalers were lost in the ice off the coast of Alaska. The New Bedford firm J. & W. R. Wing Company
column12: the largest whaling company in the United States
column13: sent out its last whaleship in 1914
column14: and whaling in New Bedford came to its final end in 1925
column15: with the last whaling expedition being made by the schooner John R. Manta.

column2: New Bedford was the site of the first petroleum fuel refinery in the United States
column3: as newly discovered Pennsylvania crude oil was shipped to New Bedford to be refined for lamp oil and other oil. Standard Oil would ultimately buy this refinery
column4: located on Fish Island. Fish Island was also the site of an early experiment in coal gasification
column5: leading to the explosion of a building.

column1: New Bedford was able to remain wealthy because of its textile industry. Starting in 1881
column2: the textile industry grew large enough to sustain the city's economy. At its height
column3: over 30
column4: 000 people were employed by the 32 cotton-manufacturing companies that owned the textile factories of New Bedford (which were worth $100 million in total). The creation of the New Bedford Textile School in 1895–1899 ushered in an era of textile prosperity that began to decline in the great depression and ended with the end of the textile period in the 1940s. The industry garnered national headlines in 1928 when it was hit with a strike of 30
column5: 000 workers. The walkout of mostly immigrant workers was given critical support by the Workers (Communist) Party and was the precursor of a more tumultuous textile strike in North Carolina held the following year.

column1: Tool and die operations also left the area steadily
column2: starting in the 1970s.

column1: New Bedford had a Class B professional Baseball team called The Whalers from 1895 to 1915. They were a member of the New England League from 1895 to 1913 and the Colonial League from 1914 to 1915. The team folded after the 1915 season. A second team called the Millmen played for one season in 1929. A second Whalers team played in the New England League in 1933–34.

column1: New Bedford is the home of the New Bedford Whaling Museum
column2: the centerpiece of the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park. It is the country's largest museum on the subject of whaling and the history of interaction between humans and whales. The museum has the skeletons of a 66-foot (20 m)-long baby blue whale (obtained in 2000)
column3: a 35-foot (11 m)-long adult humpback whale (obtained in 1900)
column4: and a 45-foot (14 m)-long sperm whale (obtained in 2004) on display. All whales died in New England waters and were cleaned and assembled for display.The Rotch-Jones-Duff House and Garden Museum is a 28-room Greek Revival mansion that was built for the whaling merchant
column5: William Rotch
column6: Jr.
column7: in 1834. Between 1834 and 1981
column8: three prominent families owned the house. It was restored by the Waterfront Historic Area LeaguE (WHALE) in the early 1980s and converted into the house museum it is today
column9: chronicling 150 years of economic
column11: and domestic life in New Bedford.The New Bedford Fire Museum is housed in a red-brick building
column13: which opened in 1867.  The fire station was one of the oldest continuously operating fire stations in the state when it was closed in 1979. The museum has a collection of old firefighting equipment and some old fire engines.  Old city fire records dating to 1890 are available for research and review. Retired and active city firefighters act as docents.

column1: The New Bedford Museum of Glass reflects the city's history as home of the Mount Washington and Pairpoint Glass companies. The museum's collection ranges from ancient to contemporary glass with a large focus on the glass of New England. A research library contains over eight thousand volumes on glass. The museum is located in one of the historic Wamsutta Mills textile factory buildings.

column1: Frederick Douglass was not the only fugitive slave or freedman to see New Bedford as a welcoming place to settle. New Bedford had a small but thriving African-American community during the antebellum period.  It was the home of a number of members of the 54th Massachusetts Regiment
